name: Kaitlin
comment info: I noticed that 37 states - more than half of all states in the U.S. - are not on track to collect responses from 99% of addresses by September 30 (as indicated by the orange graphs). 13 states, however, are on track (as indicated by the gray graphs). The states that are on track have less than 10% of addresses uncounted for. I also noticed that the graphs of each state are placed based on geographic location. Based on the graph, one can infer that the greatest percentages of people being uncounted for are located in southern states with the exception of Montana. It seems that larger states or more densely populated states have more people that are uncounted. This could be due to the difficulty of counting everyone in a state with such a large population. I wonder why people aren't filling out this census form. Is it accidental or is it on purpose? Is it because they are not educated on the process or its benefits? Do some residents not fill it out due to citizenship status? In those regards, I wonder who are the people being counted for in each state and who are not; it would be interesting to see if certain communities are more or less likely to fill out the census and any characteristics they share. This impacts my community because if not everyone is being counted, then we will not receive all the resources that we need. The census has a large impact when it comes to federal and state funding. A headline for this graph could be The 2020 Census: Who's Really Being Counted.

name: Moderator Laurie
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs:  “Uncounted and Unrepresented” by Genesis of New York, “Race of The Census: Who Will Respond?” by Kaden of Six Rivers Charter High School in Arcata, California, "Absent?: Taking Attendance in the US" by Hannah and  "Are states Down for the Count?” by Will of Dallas, Texas and "Every Response Matters: Percentage of States Collecting Enough Census Data" by Brooke of Georgia.

name: Sharon HESSNEY
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs show the projected percentage of addresses not counted by the U.S. Census by state as of September 30, 2020.  You may want to compare these state projections to the most current actual statistics.  They can be found on the U.S. Census “Total Response Rates buy State” website (https://2020census.gov/en/response-rates/nrfu.html).

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in the graphs. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included these visual representations and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Keep noticing and wondering.  Stay tuned for next week’s graph about consumer spending during the pandemic.

name: Lauren Iskander
comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice that only 13 states are on track to collect almost all of the responses for the 2020 census by September 30. That leaves most of the states – 37 to be exact– without responses from all of their residents. I notice that the states lacking full participation from their residents are highlighted in orange, while the states who received enough responses are depicted in grey. 

What do you wonder?
I wonder how significantly the lack of responses will affect the validity of the 2020 census. I wonder if the states who are lacking responses are doing anything to motivate their citizens to complete the census.

What impact does this have on you and your community?
As a resident of New Jersey, this information impacts my community because the state of New Jersey is highlighted in orange, meaning that it is not on track to receive responses from 99% of its population. Additionally, New Jersey is densely populated which most likely creates a more significant impact on the census data. The data collected from the census will determine whether or not the state government needs to improve roads or create more housing. Therefore, it is imperative that the data is accurate so my community can be served in the best way possible. 
  
Headline:
Participation paucity: 37 states not on track to collect a sufficient percentage of 2020 census responses

States Are Having Trouble Receiving Census Responses.
This graph is showing us what states are on or not on track to collect 99% of responses by September 30th. The states with the orange slopes are not on track. I wonder why certain states are farther behind on collecting responses from addresses that others. What are they doing differently than other states that are on track? The information in this graph partially impacts my community because California is behind on collecting responses but not as much as other states.

name: Ashley Nwadike
comment info: I notice that 37 state are not on track to collect responses from 99% of the addresses. The graph shows uncovered address from 2020 United States census as of September 30. I also notice the states that were counted has a lower population then the ones that are being counted. I wonder if the graph is trying to represent the household income or the amount of people living in that state. The impact that this graph has on me is it showing me the percent of people that are being uncounted for in the population and how many people are in the states. A catchy headline would be 37 states uncounted addresses in a population.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Ashley Nwadike --

You notice that “the states that were counted has a lower population then the ones that are being counted.”  Could you explain more and give some examples?  

Here are the questions that are asked by the U.S. Census:https://2020census.gov/en/about-questions.html.  Nothing on income?   The federal government asks about income in another survey.
